posts.name: Greg
posts.cooked:
Our AbsoluteEncoder offsets don’t seem to be saving when we deploy code.

Our robot is built on SDS mk4n modules, using Krakens for drive and Neos for Azimuth. We’re using CTRE Mag encoders (DIO - not Cancoder) for absolute encoders.

Our code can be found here .

When we zero our swerve modules, we open Shuffleboard and read the Raw Absolute Encoder value for each swerve module, then type that value into the Absolute Encoder Offset in each module’s configuration. This worked for us all last year using the 2024 release of YAGSL .

This year, when we zero our encoders with this method, then deploy,  the encoders are immediately wrong. This is before we apply any drive input using the gamepad.

Using FRC Web Components, I would expect the “blue” alignment of the Swerve module to match the Red. The modules haven’t been moved and the encoders were just zeroed. However, after deploying our code, this is what we see:

If we try to read the Raw Absolute Encoder value from Shuffleboard immediately after deploying, the raw value has changed, even though the modules have not moved.

Also, the Raw Absolute Encoder and Adjusted Absolute Encoder values are ALWAYS exactly the same.

image 578×572 19.4 KB

image 578×572 19.4 KB

image 578×572 19.4 KB

If we take last year’s code (and downgrade the RIO and the motor controllers to 2024 versions), this works without a problem.

Any ideas what’s going on here?

posts.name: pinkguava06
posts.cooked: I did notice in your SwerveSubsytem you have swerveDrive.pushOffsetsToEncoders(); commented out. I don’t use YAGSL but from what I understand about it you could look into that. Unless you did that on purpose. Feel free to prove me wrong, I’d like to learn more.
This sounds like your magnets are glued in. You are doing everything right! Lmk if you need anymore help!

posts.name: Sean Jameson
posts.cooked:
We were noticing the same problem where the “Adjusted” and “Raw” values were the same regardless of the offset values. We think we know what is going on and how to get around it:

We believe the 2025 YAGSL library has a bug where it reports the “Adjusted” values twice. So when you look at the telemetry data on the shuffle board, the reported “Raw Absolute Encoder” value is actually the “Adjusted Absolute Encoder” value instead.

To prove this to yourself try the following:

While disabled/off, manually turn one of the wheels so the bevel gear faces the left side of the robot. It easiest to focus on just one corner. For example, the “Back Left”.

Check the Shuffleboard value for Raw or Adjusted Absolute Encoder values (the ones that have erroneously been reporting the same). Remember that number.

In VS Code open the “backleft.json” file and change the absolute encoder offset value by 5 degrees (or any value you choose). Then push your code to the robot.

Check your shuffleboard value again after the robot reboots. Notice that BOTH the RAW and ADJUSTED values changed by 5 degrees. This is how we “proved” that it was reporting “Adjusted” values twice.

To find your actual “Raw” values you can add the “Adjusted” values being reported to your the current offset in the json files.

One last note. We haven’t gotten our drive base to drive normally yet with the 2025 library. The offset values seem fine now but despite fiddling with the “8 steps” and the PID values we are still seeing erratic behavior. Our team is contemplating reverting back to 2024 for everything until we hear the 2025 versions are more stable.

sjameson:

We believe the 2025 YAGSL library has a bug where it reports the “Adjusted” values twice

It did have that bug! Good sleuthing! It was patched and released on Saturday with version 2025.3.0

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: According to their profile, they’re on FRC team “Sean Jameson”

posts.name: Patty OBrien Novak
posts.cooked: I am using 25.3.0 and tonight, we’re seeing the adjusted absolute encoder still not reading as expected.  Any other ideas?
None without a link to your updated code

posts.name: Patty OBrien Novak
posts.cooked:
Appreciate your quick response!  We went down various paths and the swerve is working better now. Electrical team was checking wires and fuses. We double checked rotations, zeroed the mag encoders - which are very noisy.  And at one point, I had to invert 2 drive motors which had been turning the correct direction earlier in the night.  I have no idea why we needed to do that.

Really appreciate the time and effort you put into YAGSL !
